item.title: Missing links in financial inclusion
item.description:
Missing links in financial inclusion

N. RAGHAVRAMAN TANEJA FINANCE MATTERS The absence of key back-end infrastructure can act as an impediment to financial inclusion. Infrastructure facilities such as clearing houses, depositories, stock exchanges, and commodity exchanges are the backbone of any financial system.

item.title: Micro-realities of financial inclusion
item.description:
Micro-realities of financial inclusion

Low-income households need financial products that allow them to make frequent, low-value transactions. Transaction-size barriers should be as low as possible by reducing cost of service delivery. It is now well-accepted that the power of financial services to the customer, particularly low-income households, is realised only through the availability of a broad range of services, and not just through small loans or opening bank accounts.

item.title: Microfinance in India has changed overnight. Again.
item.description:
Microfinance in India has changed overnight. Again.

The Reserve Bank of India has today given "in principle" licenses to 10 new players to operate as small finance banks[1]. Like the payments banks, these entities will have 18 months to comply with all requirements and commence operations.

item.title: Payments Bank: The story lies ahead
item.description:
Payments Bank: The story lies ahead

On August 19, 2015, the Reserve Bank of India has accorded 'in principle' clearance to eleven entities to set up 'payments bank' within an eighteen month period. This is a significant development for a variety of reasons. Firstly it ends weeks of speculation on who will get the nod and brings the focus back from regulatory corridors to the market place.
